answers.body_markdown:
`char * strings[] ` is an **array of pointers**. When you initialize it as 

    char * strings[] = { "John", "Paul", NULL};

the strings `John` `Paul` are **string literals**. They are constants that exist somewhere in the code or Read only memory. What is done is to copy the pointer to the string literal `John` into the `strings[0]` and so on. i.e.

    strings[0] --> holds a pointer to "John". 
    strings[1] --> holds a pointer to "Paul"

Note that the string literals should not be modified by your program. If you do, it is undefined behaviour.

------------
In case of `char ** strings` This is a **pointer to a pointer**. It is a single memory location and cannot hold many pointers on its own.  So, you cannot initialize it as below.

    char ** strings = { "John", "Paul", NULL};  // error

However, a pointer to pointer can be used along with dynamic memory allocation (`malloc`,`calloc` etc) to point to an array of strings.

----
    char string[] = "John";

In this case, you have a **char array** into which the string literal is copied. This step is done by the compiler, generally in the start up code before the main starts.

-----
    char * string = "Paul";

Here you have a **char pointer**  which points to a string literal.

Difference between the above two statements is that in the case of a char array, you can modify the elements of `string` but you cannot in the second case.

I've tried using after:showStart and everything works fine until a show starts in the PM and ends in the AM. 

```php
$this->validate($request, [
            'showName' => 'required',
            'showDate' => 'required|date_format:m/d/Y|after_or_equal:today',
            'showStart' => 'required|date_format:g:iA',
            'showEnd' => 'required|date_format:g:iA|after:showStart'
        ]);
```



It all works great until someone enters something like:

Start Time: 11:00PM

Users enter the time in their local time zone in 12-hour format for simplicity for the user and the system converts from their local time to UTC 24-hour format. I'd prefer to keep it this way.

answers.body_markdown:
That's the Unity3d naming convention. The type, `Quaternion`, is capitalized. But they use "camel case" for properties and fields. Hence the uncapitalized `identity`.

It's completely arbitrary, but it is consistent throughout the Unity3d API.

Note that because `identity` is a static member, it is accessed via the type in which it's declared (`Quaternion`). The other members you're looking at, `transform` and `position` are both members of the current class. The `transform` property returns the transformation object for the current object, and the `position` property returns the position object for the transformation object. Because they are both class members, rather than type names, they are also camel-cased.
answers.title: Can I get an explanation about why Quaternion.identity has a capital Q but transform.position is lower case t?

answers.body_markdown:
because [`Quaternion`](https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Quaternion.html) refers to a **type** since [`idendity`](https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Quaternion-identity.html) is `static` while [`transform`](https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Component-transform.html) refers to an **instance** property of type [`Transform`](https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Transform.html) attached to the same `GameObject` as the script.

For some reason Unity uses camelCase notation for properties. Usually you would actually use PascalCase for `public` properties but those are "conventions" and basically you can decide to use other notations - at least they kept it mostly consistent.
answers.title: Can I get an explanation about why Quaternion.identity has a capital Q but transform.position is lower case t?

items.body_markdown:
Basically this program is about to find all the `neighbours` of each node basing on `seqs`. Seqs means the directivity of each node. For example, `[1, 2]` means 1 points to 2. I use dictionary to store the nodes as keys and their `neighbours` as values.

```
seqs = [[1,2],[1,3],[2,3]]
nodes = {}
neighbors = set()
for i in range(len(seqs)):
    for j in range(len(seqs[i]) - 1, 0, -1):
        neighbors.add(seqs[i][j - 1])
        nodes[seqs[i][j]] = neighbors
        print(nodes)
```

The result of nodes should be `{2: {1}, 3: {1, 2}}`, but it turned out to be `{2: {1, 2}, 3: {1, 2}}`. In the last iteration, only the value to 3 should be updated, but both values get updated. I was confused by this.

answers.body_markdown:
You seem to have put a lot of effort in your assignment. You are asking for hints and tricks how to tackle this kind of problem, so instead of giving you a full solution straight away I would like to provide a possible strategy how to build a solution step-by-step. 

Instead of trying to split the string according to whether the pen is up of down beforehand, it's easier to just loop over the whole string and deal with "T" when you encounter them in the string. After all, the only difference between the pen being up or down is whether we should store the current position for drawing or not. This means that the main part of your code will look something like. 

```
for command in a:
    # do something with command
```
Here `command` can be either a movement ("A"), a rotation ("G", or "D") or a line toggle ('T'). The first command, "A" will update the position of the turtle depending on its current position and the direction it's moving in, and "G" and "T" will update the direction the turtle is moving in. The toggle command will change whether the pen is up or down. This means that the state of the turtle can be described by three parameters: the current position, `(x,y)`, the direction the turtle is moving in, `(u, v)`, and a boolean to describe if the pen is currently up or down, `is_pen_down`. Initially, the turtle is located at `(0,0)`, and I assume is moving in the positive y-direction, i.e. `(u, v) == (0, 1)`. The pen is initially down. With this in mind, the for-loop becomes
```
x, y = (0, 0)
u, v = (0, 1)
is_pen_down = True
for command in a:
    if command == 'A':
        # move forward
    elif command == 'G':
        # rotate left
    elif command == 'D':
        # rotate right
    elif command == 'T':
        # update pen
```
The next step would be to figure out what the new position and direction of the turtle will be. 

According to the assignment, 'A' will move the turtle one step forward. This means that if `(x, y)` is the current position and `(u, v)` the current direction, the new position will be `(x+u, y+v)`. The direction will remain unchanged.

'D' will rotate the turtle 90 degrees to the right. In vector notation this means that the new direction will be `(v, -u)`. The position will stay the same in this case.

Similarly, 'G' will rotate the turtle 90 degrees to the left which means that the new direction will be `(-v, u)`. 

Using these expressions, the updated for-loop looks like:
```
x, y = (0, 0)
u, v = (0, 1)
is_pen_down = True
for command in a:
    if command == 'A':
        x += u
        y += v
    elif command == 'G':
        u, v = -v, u
    elif command == 'D':
        u, v = v, -u
    elif command == 'T':
        # update pen
```
What is left is toggling the pen and drawing the lines. For this we need to keep track of the position of the turtle while the pen is down. This can be done by appending the current x- and y-position to separate lists like in your code every time the position of the turtle is updated is the pen is down. If the pen goes up (i.e. when the command is equal to 'T' and `is_pen_down` is True), the line should be drawn and we should start a new line. Also, when the loop is finished we should remember to plot the current line if the pen is still down, and to show the plot. This means that the final program will look something like:
```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

a = 'AAAAADADAAGAAAAAAAGAADADAAAAADAAAAAAAAATDDAAAGATADAAADADAAATDAAADATAGAAAGAGAAATDADAATAAGAAGAAGAATAAATAAGAAGAAGAATDDAAAGADTADAAADADAAATATAAADADAAADATDAAAAGADTAGAAGATDAGGTAAAAAADAAAAAAAAADAAAAAATGGADTAGAAGATDADTAGAAAGAGATDAAAAAAAAADTAGAGAAAGA'

x, y = (0, 0)
u, v = (0, 1)
is_pen_down = True
outX = [x]
outY = [y]
for command in a:
    if command == 'A':
        x += u
        y += v
    elif command == 'G':
        u, v = -v, u
    elif command == 'D':
        u, v = v, -u
    elif command == 'T':
        if is_pen_down:
            # pen about to go up
            plt.plot(outX, outY)
            outX = []
            outY = []
        # toggle pen
        is_pen_down = not(is_pen_down)
    if is_pen_down:
        outX.append(x)
        outY.append(y)

# after loop, if pen is down plot open line
if is_pen_down:
    plt.plot(outX, outY)

plt.show()
```

I manage to understand how the u,v == 0,1 worked in all this. I still need to ponder on it a bit more so that I can intuitively each time understand those concept better and faster.

I've managed to combine what I was missing from your code and implemented into mine. Now I understand more on how to approach a string as a string or a list

And the result gave me this. In the end I think your way is still simpler and could attack any kind of string. Which mine would probably be more centered around 'T' being odd.

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
def get_A(x,y,u,v):
    x+=u
    y+=v
    return x,y,u,v

def get_D(u,v):        
    return v,-u

def get_G(u,v):        
    return -v,u


def get_DADE0(x,y,u,v,i):
    for letters in b[i]:                
        if letters == 'A':                              
            x,y,u,v = get_A(x,y,u,v)
            b[i] = b[i].lstrip('A')
        elif letters == 'D':
            u,v = get_D(u,v)
            b[i] = b[i].lstrip('D')
        elif letters == 'G':
            u,v = get_G(u,v)
            b[i] = b[i].lstrip('G')
        outX.append(x); outY.append(y)
    return x,y,u,v,outX,outY
         

a = str('AAAAADADAAGAAAAAAAGAADADAAAAADAAAAAAAAATDDAAAGATADAAADADAAATDAAADATAGAAAGAGAAATDADAATAAGAAGAAGAATAAATAAGAAGAAGAATDDAAAGADTADAAADADAAATATAAADADAAADATDAAAAGADTAGAAGATDAGGTAAAAAADAAAAAAAAADAAAAAATGGADTAGAAGATDADTAGAAAGAGATDAAAAAAAAADTAGAGAAAGA')
b = a.split('T')
i = 0
x,y = 0,0
u,v = 0,1


while True:
    outX, outY = [x], [y]
    if i in range (0,len(b)):
        x,y,u,v,outX,outY = get_DADE0(x,y,u,v,i)
        if i % 2 == 0:
            plt.plot(outX, outY)
            plt.axis('equal')
        i = i+1
    else:
        break
```

answers.body_markdown:
The main issue with your query is that because you have multiple rows in `tbl_fuel` that match the same `item` as in the stock update details table, you end up with multiple rows in the result set which is being summed (hence the larger than expected result). To work around this, you need to do your sums by item in each table individually, and then subtract the results:

    select susd.qty - tf.fuel_qty  as qty
    from (select susd.item, sum(susd.qty) AS qty
          from store_update_stock_details susd
          join store_update_stock sus on sus.update_stock_id = susd.update_stock_id
          where sus.status = 1
          group by item) susd
    join store_item si on susd.item = si.item_id
    join (select item, sum(fuel_qty) AS fuel_qty
          from tbl_fuel
          group by item) tf on si.item_id=tf.item

Output:

    qty
    1525

[Demo on dbfiddle][1]

 


  [1]: https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/9q6FdxtF8G7mR7WXWgudtN/0

answers.body_markdown:
PostgreSQL tries to use the index on `likes` to avoid a sort to get the top 10 results, but it has to discard many rows to get there.

Perhaps that execution plan is the best one, perhaps not.

Follow these steps:

1. Run `ANALYZE` on thee table and see if that solves the problem.

2. If not, create an index on `(domain, timestamp)` (in that order!) and see if that improves matters.

3. If that isn't sufficient, either

   - drop the index on `likes` (if you can)

   or

   - change `ORDER BY likes` into `ORDER BY likes + 0`.

If all that doesn't make it better, then your original query plan was the best, and all you can do is use more RAM in the hope that more of your data is in cache.
answers.title: Why is this pg query so slow? How can I make it faster?

answers.body_markdown:
I would suggest writing the query like this:

    SELECT ufiltered.*
    FROM (SELECT url.*,
                ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY domain ORDER BY likes DESC) AS seqnum
          FROM url 
          WHERE domain IN ('youtube.com', 'twitter.com', 'reddit.com') AND
                timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '24 hours'
        ) AS ufiltered
    WHERE seqnum <= 10
    ORDER BY timestamp DESC

For this, I would recommend an index on `url(timestamp, domain, likes)`.

answers.body_markdown:
If you just want to check if there's an angle bracket that is not closed, you don't need a fancy gem.  
You can just use `StringScanner`.

```ruby
require 'strscan'

def has_floating(html)
  open_angle = 0
  scanner = StringScanner.new(html)
  while scanner.scan(/<|>/)
    case scanner.matched
    when '<'
      return [true, '<'] if open_angle == 1
      open_angle += 1
    when '>'
      return [true, '>'] if open_angle == 0
      open_angle -= 1
    end
    scanner.scan_until(/[^<>]+/)
  end
  return false
end

myhtml = "<title> my title </title>"
puts has_floating(myhtml).inspect
#=> false

myhtml = "<title> < </title>"
puts has_floating(myhtml).inspect
#=> [true, "<"]

myhtml = "<title> > </title>"
puts has_floating(myhtml).inspect
#=> [true, ">"]
```
answers.title: Given a string of HTML, what is the best way to look for floating < >

answers.body_markdown:
I'm not going to get into the HTML part, since writing a HTML parser is a project by itself.

You can return multiple values by simply returning an array.


    def hasFloating(html)
      # extract a < or > character surrounded by two spaces
      char = html[/(?<= )[<>](?= )/]
      [!!char, char] # !!char converts char into a boolean
    end

Then use [array decomposition][1] to extract the values:

    bool, char = hasFloating("<title> my title </title>") # bool = false, char = nil
    bool, char = hasFloating("<title> < </title>")        # bool = true,  char = "<"
    bool, char = hasFloating("<title> > </title>")        # bool = true,  char = ">"


  [1]: https://ruby-doc.org/core-2.6.4/doc/syntax/assignment_rdoc.html#label-Array+Decomposition
answers.title: Given a string of HTML, what is the best way to look for floating < >

answers.body_markdown:
I think I found an answer using the `nokogiri` gem:

    htmlStr = Nokogiri::HTML(html).text
    # check for < or > in htmlSTR

It basically parses the HTML down and removes all the tags:

    html = <title> < </title>
    # parse with nokogiri
    => " < "

Which can then be used to check for floating < >.

answers.body_markdown:
Use:

    m = df['Hour'].eq(12) & df['Min'].eq(0) 
    df['Result'] = df['Bool'].shift(-1).groupby(m.cumsum()).transform('any') | df['Bool']

**Explanation**:

1. Create boolean mask by all condition to `m` with [`Series.eq`](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.Series.eq.html) for `==`  
2. Then use [`Series.shift`](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.Series.shift.html) by one row up with `-1`
3. Create groups by [`Series.cumsum`](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.Series.cumsum.html)
4. Use [`GroupBy.transform`](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.core.groupby.GroupBy.transform.html) with [`GroupBy.any`](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.core.groupby.GroupBy.any.html) for test `True` per groups by `g`
5. Last chain boolean column with `|` for bitwise OR

---

    m = df['Hour'].eq(12) & df['Min'].eq(0) 
    
    print (df.assign(m = df['Hour'].eq(12) & df['Min'].eq(0),
                     shift = df['Bool'].shift(-1),
                     g = m.cumsum(),
                     transform = df['Bool'].shift(-1).groupby(m.cumsum()).transform('any'),
                     Result=df['Bool'].shift(-1).groupby(m.cumsum()).transform('any')|df['Bool']))

    0   False    12    0   True  False  1      False   False
    1   False    12   30  False  False  1      False   False
    2   False    24    0  False  False  1      False   False
    3   False    24   30  False  False  1      False   False
    4   False    12    0   True  False  2       True    True
    5   False    12   30  False  False  2       True    True

answers.body_markdown:
> all my updates on the remote repository are gone

When you force push from home to office, you overrode the history of the master branch of office.

When you will have access your office, you can use [`git reflog`][1] to list the commit which was *before* your latest forced push. You can [reset it to its old state][2].

Then, from home:

- clone office repo again (in a new folder)
- report your latest changes
- add, commit, and push

----

More generally, for synchronizing files, [Steve Gibson][3] mentions several alternatives in:

- "[Steve’s File Sync Journey][4]": see transcript in "[`sn-726.txt`][5]".
- "[The Joy of Sync][6]"

Mainly:

- [Sync.com][7] (free tier with 5GB)
- [syncthing][8] (opensource)


  [1]: https://git-scm.com/docs/git-reflog
  [2]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/12569664/6309
  [3]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Gibson_(computer_programmer)
  [4]: https://twit.tv/shows/security-now/episodes/726
  [5]: https://www.grc.com/sn/sn-726.txt
  [6]: https://www.grc.com/sn/sn-734-notes.pdf
  [7]: https://www.sync.com
  [8]: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing
answers.title: I made a mess with git, can someone explain me what I did wrong?

answers.body_markdown:
What might have happened is you edited history with something like a rebase, or you happened to be in a different branch that didn't have your updates. Git gives you that warning when the history of your branches isn't compatible, and `--force` overwrites that history instead of simply adding new commits. I like to use `git push`, and default to the branch with the same name, instead of `git push origin master`. That helps prevent something like pushing to master from the wrong, out of date branch.

The good thing about git is that it doesn't delete commits, it only creates new ones. Your computer with the correct updates still has them. You can find them with `git reflog`. That shows you the history of your HEAD commit, which changes as you do your work. You can find the commit that looks right and run `git checkout <commit-id>` to see if that's the state you want. Then you can either create a new branch at that commit (`git checkout -b recovery-test`), or just switch back to master and reset master to that commit (`git checkout master`; `git reset <commit-id>`).

**But You Can Use Below Method to Test You App**

It looks like both linux DAC and SE-Android are blocking your application's process from accessing the 'su' executable.

Check if your system is running in enforced mode, meaning that SE-Android is enabled. If this is indeed the case, you can temporarily disable it by running:

    adb root

This will disable SE-Android and will not block the apps process from executing 'su'.

Please note that building a custom userdebug image is not quite like rooting a standard Android device. The debug version is meant to allow access to the device's internals while still simulating a real functioning device with all of its default security mechanisms enabled.

answers.body_markdown:
>Why isn't my outcome function breaking out of the while loop?

Because `ini` is still equal to 1. Your main function has a local variable named `ini`, so even if you set the global `ini` from `outcome`, it will be ignored.

You should not use a global variable for this. You have the right idea with `return ini`. However, the calling code does not care about this *name* - it only cares about the *value*. When you call `outcome` and X has won, it will `return` the value of `0`. You should assign this:

    ini = outcome(gboard)

The next step is that `outcome` needs to return a value even if X did *not* win. (And, of course, you should test for the other ways that X can win, and that O can win.) You can use multiple different values to indicate who won, or if the game should continue.

This is a simple problem of assignment, but [you should not use `iterrows`](https://stackoverflow.com/a/55557758/4909087), and especially not when you want to mutate your DataFrame.  

Use a list comprehension instead and assign this back as a new column.

    df['hex'] = [rgb_to_hex(*v) for v in df.values]
    # Or, if you have more than three columns,
    # df['hex'] = [rgb_to_hex(*v) for v in df[['red', 'green', 'blue']].values]
    
       red  green  blue      hex
    0    0      0     0  #000000
    1    0      0     0  #000000

From [what I find](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54028199/are-for-loops-in-pandas-really-bad-when-should-i-care/54028200#54028200), list comprehensions can be very fast as the next alternative to a non-vectorizable problem.

answers.body_markdown:
Your specific expressions (`(i % k)` and `(l % k)` ) are irrelevant for the question. It can be rephrased like: "given `int a, b;`, what is the difference between `a==b==0` and `a==0 && b==0`. 

The first of these expressions (`a==b==0`) is almost certainly not what you meant (this is not Python!). It is equivalent to `(a==b)==0`, which in turn is equivalent to `a!=b`. 

The second one (`a==0 && b==0`) is what you expect: "both `a` and `b` are zero".
answers.title: C++ syntax, difference between i % k == l % k == 0 and i % k == 0 && l % k == 0

answers.body_markdown:
[cppreference][1] is a good place to check on c++ operator precedence and associativity.

Since `==` operator has left-to-right associativity, your first expression is equivalent to 

```c++
if (((i % k) == (l % k)) == 0)
```

which first checks whether `(i % k) == (l % k)`, which evaluates to a `bool`, and then compare the `bool` to zero. A bool `== 0` when it is `false`. Thus, it is also equivalent to:

```c++
if ((i % k) != (l % k))
```
Note you can also remove parentheses around the modulo operation, because `%` has higher precedence than `==`.

Your second example might be what you really want: checking whether both `(i % k) == 0` and `(l % k) == 0`.


  [1]: https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/operator_precedence
answers.title: C++ syntax, difference between i % k == l % k == 0 and i % k == 0 && l % k == 0

Instead of storing your instances of the class in separate variables, store them as values in a dictionary:

    options = {
        "option_a": UserSelect("Option A", "This is option A.", True, myfunc_a),
        "option_b": UserSelect("Option B", "This is option B.", True, myfunc_b)
    }

And ensure that one of the methods provided by the class will actually call the stored function:

    class UserSelect:
        # other stuff...
        def invoke(self):
            # add whatever logic is needed to determine the parameters for the call...
            self.action()

And then use the user's string input as a key for the dictionary, get the corresponding instance and call the method:

    userin = input("What would you like to do? ")
    options[userin].invoke()

answers.body_markdown:
`setTimeout` is scalable provided the scalability/performance [advise](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38276583/how-many-concurrent-settimeouts-before-performance-issues) is followed. The issue here is that `setTimeout` approach is not durable e.g. the functionality will be broken for some users if the server/container that hosts Express reboots. The other issue is that it will not work if you have multiple Express instances.

In case there is one Express instance using Redis will change neither scalability nor durability unless you enable Redis persistence to survive restarts/reboots or unless you use more than one Redis node.  

In case there are multiple Express instances using Redis is the way to go.

answers.title: Loopback/express marking items for deletion after a time period

items.body_markdown:
I have a model `Item` which stores user items. This model has a field `endDate` at which the instances have to be marked for deletion by setting `expired` field to true. Is there some way I can do this in loopback/express automatically? I am using `postgresql` as database. 

I can think of following 2 ways but I don't think they are the best solutions for this problem:

1) Using `setTimeout` I can call a function which would mark the items for deletion. This solution is not at all scalable as it is not `stateless` and if there are multiple instances of `node` running, this would cause issues.

2) Use `redis` database and for each item create a key in `redis` with expire time. `redis` will automatically call a function when the timer expires and I can delete the item then. This I think is scalable as this is `stateless`.

Is there a more efficient solution to this?

**Edit**

I want to notify the user also as soon as the item expires. So, I would need a function call to happen as soon as expiration happens. So setting expireAt key and running a cleanup utility at intervals, will not be of much help here.
items.title: Loopback/express marking items for deletion after a time period

items.body_markdown:
I am not understanding the purpose of separating Image and PhotoImage objects in Tkinter and having trouble finding complete documentation on either. Am I understanding correctly that a .png file must be first opened with 'Image.open', then converted with 'ImageTk.PhotoImage' before being displayed in a widget? Since I have to keep a reference to the object, I open it using 'self.background_image = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open('my_image.png'))'  
Then I display it on a canvas using 'create_image'. Supposedly the PhotoImage objects have a 'copy()' method, but when I call 'copy = self.background_image.copy()', I get 'PhotoImage object has no attribute copy' error.  

What I am trying to do is dynamically open new .png files and combine them with the background image. The preexisting background does not need to contain/display transparent pixels, but does currently exist as 'rgba' filetype. The newly opened files do need to display as transparencies.  

Apparently both PhotoImage and Image objects have a 'paste' method, but the PhotoImage method does not take a mask as an argument. So if I call 'self.background_image.paste(new_image,(0,0))' the transparent portions of the new image display as black pixels.   

I cannot re-open the background image as an Image object since it needs to dynamically change while being displayed in a widget (needs to be a PhotoImage).   

How can I do alpha-composites or pastes that contain transparencies on a PhotoImage object that is currently being displayed?
items.title: How do I alpha composite a displayed PhotoImage object in Python Tkinter?
